instrument: Reading comprehension data from an RCT
instructions: Now you will read the passage silently by yourself and then answer the questions. There are 4 answer choices for each question but only one correct answer. Choose the answer that you think is correct. You may begin.
section_prompt: Looking for the Titanic: (1) During its first journey in 1912, a ship called the Titanic ran into a giant iceberg. It sank to the bottom of the ocean. Scientists wondered if it could be found. What did it look like? Until 1985, nobody could find the Titanic. Americans were able to send astronauts like Neil Armstrong to the moon before finding the Titanic. (2) There are many obstacles to exploring the bottom of the ocean. (3) First, scientists need to be persistent. It is very difficult to see the bottom of the ocean. Scientists needed to create new inventions to find the Titanic. (4) Second, the voyage to the bottom of the ocean is hard for people. Scientists need to build new equipment that can withstand the water pressure far below the surface of the water. (5) One solution is to experiment with new equipment. In 1985, scientists from different countries designed an underwater camera called Argo. (6) Argo was an ingenious invention. It was like a human eyeball. On August 31, 1985, Argo's cameras took a picture of a huge piece of equipment. It was the boilers that burned coal to drive a ship's engines. It was clear that the boilers belonged to the Titanic. (7) Nearly one year later, three adventurous scientists were ready to explore the Titanic in person. They went inside a submarine called Alvin. It could hold three people. It took them to the final destination. With the help of Alvin, scientists explored the ocean floor in person. They found stairs, lights, pots, and pans. It was like a huge underwater museum. (8) After Alvin helped scientists explore the Titanic, President Reagan created a museum to celebrate the discovery. (9) Scientists, engineers, and inventors had collaborate to make invent new machines to find and explore the Titanic. In addition to the Titanic, this work helped explore other shipwrecks.
item_text: According to the passage, why did the Titanic sink?
option_text: The Titanic was hit by the Argo
construct_name: Modeling Item-Level Heterogeneous Treatment Effects With the Explanatory Item Response Model: Leveraging Large-Scale Online Assessments to Pinpoint the Impact of Educational Interventions
title: Replication Data for: Modeling Item-Level Heterogeneous Treatment Effects With the Explanatory Item Response Model: Leveraging Large-Scale Online Assessments to Pinpoint the Impact of Educational Interventions
author: Josh Gilbert

instrument: Reading comprehension data from an RCT
instructions: Now you will read the passage silently by yourself and then answer the questions. There are 4 answer choices for each question but only one correct answer. Choose the answer that you think is correct. You may begin.
section_prompt: Monkeys: (1) A human is a primate. In primates, the heart sends oxygen in the blood all around the body. The body must have oxygen to function properly. The strong heart muscle contracts to pump blood all around the body. A healthy heart never rests. (2) But what happens when a person's heart gets weaker? People with weak hearts need help. Scientists have to study a medical mystery. Then they might be able to help people. (3) First, scientists need to diagnose the reasons that a human heart gets weak. They need to do tests. But sometimes it would be hard on a sick person to have tests done. So, scientists study animals that have body systems like humans. Scientists knew that the structure of the macaque monkey's heart is like the human heart. So, they did tests with macaque monkeys. The scientists learned what happens when a monkey has a heart attack. After a heart attack, the monkey's heart muscle has scar tissue where it as damaged. The scar tissue cannot contract like a strong heart muscle can. Then the monkey's heart cannot pump enough blood to give the body the oxygen it needs. Without enough oxygen, the monkey's body cannot function properly. (4) Second, scientists wanted to try out new solutions that would keep the heart working. Sometimes the new solutions might fail. So, scientists didn't want to try the solutions with people right away. They tried a solution with macaque monkeys. (5) Scientists developed an idea. Then, they tested an idea. They injected human stem cells from the human heart into the monkey's heart. After four weeks the human heart cells grew where the monkey's scar tissue was. After three months, the monkey's heart got stronger. (6) Now scientists are using what they found in this experiment to help humans who have had heart attacks.
item_text: According to paragraph 3, why do scientists study macaque monkeys?
option_text: Their heart muscles have scar tissue
construct_name: Modeling Item-Level Heterogeneous Treatment Effects With the Explanatory Item Response Model: Leveraging Large-Scale Online Assessments to Pinpoint the Impact of Educational Interventions
title: Replication Data for: Modeling Item-Level Heterogeneous Treatment Effects With the Explanatory Item Response Model: Leveraging Large-Scale Online Assessments to Pinpoint the Impact of Educational Interventions

instructions: Now you will read the passage silently by yourself and then answer the questions. There are 4 answer choices for each question but only one correct answer. Choose the answer that you think is correct. You may begin.
section_prompt: Monkeys: (1) A human is a primate. In primates, the heart sends oxygen in the blood all around the body. The body must have oxygen to function properly. The strong heart muscle contracts to pump blood all around the body. A healthy heart never rests. (2) But what happens when a person's heart gets weaker? People with weak hearts need help. Scientists have to study a medical mystery. Then they might be able to help people. (3) First, scientists need to diagnose the reasons that a human heart gets weak. They need to do tests. But sometimes it would be hard on a sick person to have tests done. So, scientists study animals that have body systems like humans. Scientists knew that the structure of the macaque monkey's heart is like the human heart. So, they did tests with macaque monkeys. The scientists learned what happens when a monkey has a heart attack. After a heart attack, the monkey's heart muscle has scar tissue where it as damaged. The scar tissue cannot contract like a strong heart muscle can. Then the monkey's heart cannot pump enough blood to give the body the oxygen it needs. Without enough oxygen, the monkey's body cannot function properly. (4) Second, scientists wanted to try out new solutions that would keep the heart working. Sometimes the new solutions might fail. So, scientists didn't want to try the solutions with people right away. They tried a solution with macaque monkeys. (5) Scientists developed an idea. Then, they tested an idea. They injected human stem cells from the human heart into the monkey's heart. After four weeks the human heart cells grew where the monkey's scar tissue was. After three months, the monkey's heart got stronger. (6) Now scientists are using what they found in this experiment to help humans who have had heart attacks.
item_text: Why do scientists study monkey hearts?
option_text: Because they want to help humans who have heart attacks

section_prompt: Exploring Mars: (1) One of Earth's closest neighbors is the planet Mars. Scientists are curious about Mars. Is it like Earth? Is there life there? Could people live there? People want to learn about Mars. No one has made the long voyage there. Not even Neil Armstrong has explored Mars. (2) People need to overcome many obstacles to explore Mars. (3) First, astronauts need to be adventurous. It takes nearly 9 months to get to Mars. Astronauts need to invent new ways of eating in space. They need to experiment with ways to grow fruits and vegetables in space during the journey to Mars. (4) Second, astronauts need to be brave. There is little gravity during the journey. Weightlessness can weaken the bones and muscles in people and this can be bad for their health. This voyage will be one very long experiment. Scientists will be able to study what happens to the astronauts' skeletal and muscular system. (5) One solution is to experiment with new equipment. Instead of sending astronauts to Mars, in 2011 scientists sent a robot named Curiosity to Mars. (6) The NASA team collaborated to build Curiosity. It took engineers to build the motor and wheels. It took inventors to build special cameras to take pictures of Mars. It was an ingenious invention. Curiosity's job was to run lots of experiments. It looked for evidence of water in the soil and for habitats where things could live. (7) When Curiosity landed on Mars, President Obama said, "Curiosity is going to tell us things we did not know before." (8) In 2012, Curiosity made history by exploring Mars. It has made many important contributions to science. (9) Scientists are learning more about Mars, and NASA is planning more journeys to Mars. Many scientists, leaders, and engineers had to collaborate to invent new machines to explore Mars.
item_text: According to paragraph 3, why do scientists need to figure out how to grow food in space?
option_text: To see how gravity affects food in space

section_prompt: Looking for the Titanic: (1) During its first journey in 1912, a ship called the Titanic ran into a giant iceberg. It sank to the bottom of the ocean. Scientists wondered if it could be found. What did it look like? Until 1985, nobody could find the Titanic. Americans were able to send astronauts like Neil Armstrong to the moon before finding the Titanic. (2) There are many obstacles to exploring the bottom of the ocean. (3) First, scientists need to be persistent. It is very difficult to see the bottom of the ocean. Scientists needed to create new inventions to find the Titanic. (4) Second, the voyage to the bottom of the ocean is hard for people. Scientists need to build new equipment that can withstand the water pressure far below the surface of the water. (5) One solution is to experiment with new equipment. In 1985, scientists from different countries designed an underwater camera called Argo. (6) Argo was an ingenious invention. It was like a human eyeball. On August 31, 1985, Argo's cameras took a picture of a huge piece of equipment. It was the boilers that burned coal to drive a ship's engines. It was clear that the boilers belonged to the Titanic. (7) Nearly one year later, three adventurous scientists were ready to explore the Titanic in person. They went inside a submarine called Alvin. It could hold three people. It took them to the final destination. With the help of Alvin, scientists explored the ocean floor in person. They found stairs, lights, pots, and pans. It was like a huge underwater museum. (8) After Alvin helped scientists explore the Titanic, President Reagan created a museum to celebrate the discovery. (9) Scientists, engineers, and inventors had collaborate to make invent new machines to find and explore the Titanic. In addition to the Titanic, this work helped explore other shipwrecks.
item_text: Which sentence best summarizes paragraph 4?
option_text: Scientists wanted to explore the Titanic.

It was like a human eyeball. On August 31, 1985, Argo's cameras took a picture of a huge piece of equipment. It was the boilers that burned coal to drive a ship's engines. It was clear that the boilers belonged to the Titanic. (7) Nearly one year later, three adventurous scientists were ready to explore the Titanic in person. They went inside a submarine called Alvin. It could hold three people. It took them to the final destination. With the help of Alvin, scientists explored the ocean floor in person. They found stairs, lights, pots, and pans. It was like a huge underwater museum. (8) After Alvin helped scientists explore the Titanic, President Reagan created a museum to celebrate the discovery. (9) Scientists, engineers, and inventors had collaborate to make invent new machines to find and explore the Titanic. In addition to the Titanic, this work helped explore other shipwrecks.

author: Josh Gilbert

instrument: Reading comprehension data from an RCT
instructions: Now you will read the passage silently by yourself and then answer the questions. There are 4 answer choices for each question but only one correct answer. Choose the answer that you think is correct. You may begin.
section_prompt: Monkeys: (1) A human is a primate. In primates, the heart sends oxygen in the blood all around the body. The body must have oxygen to function properly. The strong heart muscle contracts to pump blood all around the body. A healthy heart never rests. (2) But what happens when a person's heart gets weaker? People with weak hearts need help. Scientists have to study a medical mystery. Then they might be able to help people. (3) First, scientists need to diagnose the reasons that a human heart gets weak. They need to do tests. But sometimes it would be hard on a sick person to have tests done. So, scientists study animals that have body systems like humans. Scientists knew that the structure of the macaque monkey's heart is like the human heart. So, they did tests with macaque monkeys. The scientists learned what happens when a monkey has a heart attack. After a heart attack, the monkey's heart muscle has scar tissue where it as damaged. The scar tissue cannot contract like a strong heart muscle can. Then the monkey's heart cannot pump enough blood to give the body the oxygen it needs. Without enough oxygen, the monkey's body cannot function properly. (4) Second, scientists wanted to try out new solutions that would keep the heart working. Sometimes the new solutions might fail. So, scientists didn't want to try the solutions with people right away. They tried a solution with macaque monkeys. (5) Scientists developed an idea. Then, they tested an idea. They injected human stem cells from the human heart into the monkey's heart. After four weeks the human heart cells grew where the monkey's scar tissue was. After three months, the monkey's heart got stronger. (6) Now scientists are using what they found in this experiment to help humans who have had heart attacks.

instrument: Reading comprehension data from an RCT
instructions: Now you will read the passage silently by yourself and then answer the questions. There are 4 answer choices for each question but only one correct answer. Choose the answer that you think is correct. You may begin.
section_prompt: Exploring Mars: (1) One of Earth's closest neighbors is the planet Mars. Scientists are curious about Mars. Is it like Earth? Is there life there? Could people live there? People want to learn about Mars. No one has made the long voyage there. Not even Neil Armstrong has explored Mars. (2) People need to overcome many obstacles to explore Mars. (3) First, astronauts need to be adventurous. It takes nearly 9 months to get to Mars. Astronauts need to invent new ways of eating in space. They need to experiment with ways to grow fruits and vegetables in space during the journey to Mars. (4) Second, astronauts need to be brave. There is little gravity during the journey. Weightlessness can weaken the bones and muscles in people and this can be bad for their health. This voyage will be one very long experiment. Scientists will be able to study what happens to the astronauts' skeletal and muscular system. (5) One solution is to experiment with new equipment. Instead of sending astronauts to Mars, in 2011 scientists sent a robot named Curiosity to Mars. (6) The NASA team collaborated to build Curiosity. It took engineers to build the motor and wheels. It took inventors to build special cameras to take pictures of Mars. It was an ingenious invention. Curiosity's job was to run lots of experiments. It looked for evidence of water in the soil and for habitats where things could live. (7) When Curiosity landed on Mars, President Obama said, "Curiosity is going to tell us things we did not know before." (8) In 2012, Curiosity made history by exploring Mars. It has made many important contributions to science. (9) Scientists are learning more about Mars, and NASA is planning more journeys to Mars. Many scientists, leaders, and engineers had to collaborate to invent new machines to explore Mars.
item_text: Which sentence best summarizes the last paragraph?
option_text: People had to collaborate to build Curiosity

section_prompt: Now we are going to play a listening game about the sounds at the beginning of a word. The word cat starts with the /c/ sound. Listen to the words I say and tell me which one starts with the same sound /c/ like cat. mouse, cup, friend. In this one, cat and cup both have the /c/ sound at the beginning!
item_text: Q1: Let's do another one. Ready? name starts with the /n/ sound. Now listen to these words and tell me which one starts with the /n/ sound like name. baby, toes, neck. Q2: Let's do another one. Ready? pen starts with the /p/ sound. Now listen to these words and tell me which one starts with the /p/ sound like pen. sat, pig, man. Q3: Let's do another one. Ready? hat starts with the /h/ sound. Listen to these words and tell me which one starts with the /h/ sound like hat. head, feet, rat.
construct_name: Reading assessment
title: Replication Data for: Improving reading proficiency in early childhood education classrooms, Evidence from Liberia

instructions: The questions in this scale ask about your feelings and thoughts during the last month. In each case, you will be asked to indicate how often you felt or thought a certain way. Although some of the questions are similar, there are differences between them and you should treat each one as a separate question. The best approach is to answer fairly quickly. That is, don’t try to count up the number of times you felt a particular way; rather indicate the alternative that seems like a reasonable estimate. For each question choose from the following alternatives: 0-never 1-almost never 2-sometimes 3-fairly often 4-very often

author: James S Kim and Joshua B. Gilbert and Jackie E. Relyea and Patrick Rich and Ethan Scherer and Mary A. Burkhauser and Johanna N. Tvedt

instrument: Comprehension test following a reading intervention
instructions: Now you will read the passage silently by yourself and then answer the questions. There are 4 answer choices for each question but only one correct answer. Choose the answer that you think is correct. You may begin.
section_prompt: Some birds that are here today are smaller than they were many years ago. Why is this happening? It is a mystery. How do scientists study a mystery? First, scientists try to understand the bird’s skeletal and muscular systems. Those systems help birds to fly. One thing scientists know is that birds’ bones are hollow inside. So, they don’t weigh much. Birds’ skeletons weigh less than their feathers. They have also learned that a bird wing works like a human arm. Birds contract their chest muscles to make their wings flap. Second, scientists try to diagnose the reasons that the birds’ bodies might have changed over time. Some scientists thought that birds’ skeletal or muscular systems might have changed. So, they studied migratory birds in North America. Migratory birds fly long distances to warmer places for the winter. Third, scientists measured the physical characteristics of the birds. They measured the size of the birds’ bones. They found some of the birds’ bones were shorter than they were 40 years ago. For example, the lower leg bone of many birds is smaller. Fourth, scientists measured the migratory birds’ wings. They found the birds’ wings are longer than they used to be. Many scientists asked, “Why are the birds’ bones smaller than they used be. But their wings are longer?” They thought about the long distance the birds fly in winter. They thought that the birds’ bodies changed to adapt to the long winter flight. They would need a lot of energy for the flight. A smaller body would have smaller muscles and less fat. But smaller bones and longer wings would make flying easier. Over time, these characteristics of birds have become more common. The scientists came up with some very good ideas about why these skeletal changes might be occurring.
item_text: What is the main question that scientists are trying to answer in this passage?
option_text: How do birds fly long distances?
construct_name: Domain-Specific (Science) Reading Comprehension
title: Replication Data for: Time to Transfer: Long-Term Effects of a Sustained and Spiraled Content Literacy Intervention in the Elementary Grades

title: Replication Data for: Time to Transfer: Long-Term Effects of a Sustained and Spiraled Content Literacy Intervention in the Elementary Grades
author: James S Kim and Joshua B. Gilbert and Jackie E. Relyea and Patrick Rich and Ethan Scherer and Mary A. Burkhauser and Johanna N. Tvedt

instrument: Comprehension test following a reading intervention
instructions: Now you will read the passage silently by yourself and then answer the questions. There are 4 answer choices for each question but only one correct answer. Choose the answer that you think is correct. You may begin.
section_prompt: In many ways, skyscrapers are like the human body. They have bones that keep it tall and strong and skin to protect the body. They have a command center that is like a brain. How do engineers design and build strong and smart skyscrapers? It is very challenging to build a skyscraper because there are many parts that have to work together. If one part is broken, the skyscraper will not work properly. First, engineers need a strong and tall frame that supports the floors and walls. This frame is like the bones of a skyscraper. The bones of a skyscraper are made of concrete, steel and other materials. The columns are like the backbone of a human body. The columns go up. The steel columns hold up each floor. There are also steel beams that go across each floor. The steel columns and beams must be strong to resist the force of gravity. The steel columns and beams must work together to form a strong backbone. Second, engineers need to design a command center. The command center is a computer that sends signals through wires in a skyscraper. For example, it sends signals to help bring fresh air into rooms, just like your lungs. The command center also controls the heating and air conditioning. It helps the building cool down when it’s too hot and warm up when it’s too cold. A skyscraper has many different parts that work together. The bones make the building tall and strong. The skin protects the inside of the building. The skin of a skyscraper can be made of metal, stone, or glass. The brain controls the building temperature. The anatomy of a skyscraper is like a human body. All the parts have to work together. That's how a city skyscraper works properly.
item_text: What does the author think is special about the beams and columns of a skyscraper?
option_text: They are made of many different materials

construct_name: Domain-Specific (Science) Reading Comprehension
title: Replication Data for: Time to Transfer: Long-Term Effects of a Sustained and Spiraled Content Literacy Intervention in the Elementary Grades
author: James S Kim and Joshua B. Gilbert and Jackie E. Relyea and Patrick Rich and Ethan Scherer and Mary A. Burkhauser and Johanna N. Tvedt

instrument: Comprehension test following a reading intervention
instructions: Now you will read the passage silently by yourself and then answer the questions. There are 4 answer choices for each question but only one correct answer. Choose the answer that you think is correct. You may begin.
section_prompt: A human is a primate. In primates, the heart sends oxygen in the blood all around the body. The body must have oxygen to function properly. The strong heart muscle contracts to pump blood all around the body. A healthy heart never rests. But what happens when a person’s heart gets weaker? People with weak hearts need help. Scientists have to study a medical mystery. Then they might be able to help people. First, scientists need to diagnose the reasons that a human heart gets weak. They need to do tests. But sometimes it would be hard on a sick person to have tests done. So, scientists study animals that have body systems like humans. Scientists knew that the macaque monkey’s heart is similar to the human heart. So, they did tests with macaque monkeys. The scientists learned what happens when a monkey has a heart attack. After a heart attack, the monkey’s heart muscle has scar tissue where it was damaged. The scar tissue cannot contract like a strong heart muscle can. Then the monkey’s heart cannot pump enough blood to give the body the oxygen it needs. Without enough oxygen, the monkey’s body cannot function properly. Second, scientists wanted to try out new solutions that would keep the heart working. Sometimes the new solutions might fail. So, scientists didn’t want to try the solutions with people right away. They tried a solution with macaque monkeys. Scientists developed an idea. Then, they tested an idea. They injected human stem cells from the human heart into the monkey’s heart. After four weeks the human heart cells grew where the monkey’s scar tissue was. After three months, the monkey’s heart got stronger. Now scientists are using what they found in this experiment to help humans who have had heart attacks.
item_text: According to paragraph 3, why do scientists study macaque monkeys?
construct_name: Domain-Specific (Science) Reading Comprehension
title: Replication Data for: Time to Transfer: Long-Term Effects of a Sustained and Spiraled Content Literacy Intervention in the Elementary Grades

instructions: Now you will read the passage silently by yourself and then answer the questions. There are 4 answer choices for each question but only one correct answer. Choose the answer that you think is correct. You may begin.
section_prompt: In many ways, skyscrapers are like the human body. They have bones that keep it tall and strong and skin to protect the body. They have a command center that is like a brain. How do engineers design and build strong and smart skyscrapers? It is very challenging to build a skyscraper because there are many parts that have to work together. If one part is broken, the skyscraper will not work properly. First, engineers need a strong and tall frame that supports the floors and walls. This frame is like the bones of a skyscraper. The bones of a skyscraper are made of concrete, steel and other materials. The columns are like the backbone of a human body. The columns go up. The steel columns hold up each floor. There are also steel beams that go across each floor. The steel columns and beams must be strong to resist the force of gravity. The steel columns and beams must work together to form a strong backbone. Second, engineers need to design a command center. The command center is a computer that sends signals through wires in a skyscraper. For example, it sends signals to help bring fresh air into rooms, just like your lungs. The command center also controls the heating and air conditioning. It helps the building cool down when it’s too hot and warm up when it’s too cold. A skyscraper has many different parts that work together. The bones make the building tall and strong. The skin protects the inside of the building. The skin of a skyscraper can be made of metal, stone, or glass. The brain controls the building temperature. The anatomy of a skyscraper is like a human body. All the parts have to work together. That's how a city skyscraper works properly.
item_text: According to paragraph 4, a skyscraper’s command center is like the human body’s

title: Replication Data for: Time to Transfer: Long-Term Effects of a Sustained and Spiraled Content Literacy Intervention in the Elementary Grades
author: James S Kim and Joshua B. Gilbert and Jackie E. Relyea and Patrick Rich and Ethan Scherer and Mary A. Burkhauser and Johanna N. Tvedt

instrument: Comprehension test following a reading intervention
instructions: Now you will read the passage silently by yourself and then answer the questions. There are 4 answer choices for each question but only one correct answer. Choose the answer that you think is correct. You may begin.
section_prompt: A human is a primate. In primates, the heart sends oxygen in the blood all around the body. The body must have oxygen to function properly. The strong heart muscle contracts to pump blood all around the body. A healthy heart never rests. But what happens when a person’s heart gets weaker? People with weak hearts need help. Scientists have to study a medical mystery. Then they might be able to help people. First, scientists need to diagnose the reasons that a human heart gets weak. They need to do tests. But sometimes it would be hard on a sick person to have tests done. So, scientists study animals that have body systems like humans. Scientists knew that the macaque monkey’s heart is similar to the human heart. So, they did tests with macaque monkeys. The scientists learned what happens when a monkey has a heart attack. After a heart attack, the monkey’s heart muscle has scar tissue where it was damaged. The scar tissue cannot contract like a strong heart muscle can. Then the monkey’s heart cannot pump enough blood to give the body the oxygen it needs. Without enough oxygen, the monkey’s body cannot function properly. Second, scientists wanted to try out new solutions that would keep the heart working. Sometimes the new solutions might fail. So, scientists didn’t want to try the solutions with people right away. They tried a solution with macaque monkeys. Scientists developed an idea. Then, they tested an idea. They injected human stem cells from the human heart into the monkey’s heart. After four weeks the human heart cells grew where the monkey’s scar tissue was. After three months, the monkey’s heart got stronger. Now scientists are using what they found in this experiment to help humans who have had heart attacks.
item_text: What medical mystery are scientists trying to study in this passage?
option_text: How to help macaque monkeys stay strong
construct_name: Domain-Specific (Science) Reading Comprehension

title: Replication Data for: Time to Transfer: Long-Term Effects of a Sustained and Spiraled Content Literacy Intervention in the Elementary Grades
author: James S Kim and Joshua B. Gilbert and Jackie E. Relyea and Patrick Rich and Ethan Scherer and Mary A. Burkhauser and Johanna N. Tvedt

instrument: Comprehension test following a reading intervention
instructions: Now you will read the passage silently by yourself and then answer the questions. There are 4 answer choices for each question but only one correct answer. Choose the answer that you think is correct. You may begin.
section_prompt: Some birds that are here today are smaller than they were many years ago. Why is this happening? It is a mystery. How do scientists study a mystery? First, scientists try to understand the bird’s skeletal and muscular systems. Those systems help birds to fly. One thing scientists know is that birds’ bones are hollow inside. So, they don’t weigh much. Birds’ skeletons weigh less than their feathers. They have also learned that a bird wing works like a human arm. Birds contract their chest muscles to make their wings flap. Second, scientists try to diagnose the reasons that the birds’ bodies might have changed over time. Some scientists thought that birds’ skeletal or muscular systems might have changed. So, they studied migratory birds in North America. Migratory birds fly long distances to warmer places for the winter. Third, scientists measured the physical characteristics of the birds. They measured the size of the birds’ bones. They found some of the birds’ bones were shorter than they were 40 years ago. For example, the lower leg bone of many birds is smaller. Fourth, scientists measured the migratory birds’ wings. They found the birds’ wings are longer than they used to be. Many scientists asked, “Why are the birds’ bones smaller than they used be. But their wings are longer?” They thought about the long distance the birds fly in winter. They thought that the birds’ bodies changed to adapt to the long winter flight. They would need a lot of energy for the flight. A smaller body would have smaller muscles and less fat. But smaller bones and longer wings would make flying easier. Over time, these characteristics of birds have become more common. The scientists came up with some very good ideas about why these skeletal changes might be occurring.
item_text: Which sentence best summarizes paragraph 2?
option_text: Scientists worked to learn about birds’ bones and wings
construct_name: Domain-Specific (Science) Reading Comprehension

section_prompt: In many ways, skyscrapers are like the human body. They have bones that keep it tall and strong and skin to protect the body. They have a command center that is like a brain. How do engineers design and build strong and smart skyscrapers? It is very challenging to build a skyscraper because there are many parts that have to work together. If one part is broken, the skyscraper will not work properly. First, engineers need a strong and tall frame that supports the floors and walls. This frame is like the bones of a skyscraper. The bones of a skyscraper are made of concrete, steel and other materials. The columns are like the backbone of a human body. The columns go up. The steel columns hold up each floor. There are also steel beams that go across each floor. The steel columns and beams must be strong to resist the force of gravity. The steel columns and beams must work together to form a strong backbone. Second, engineers need to design a command center. The command center is a computer that sends signals through wires in a skyscraper. For example, it sends signals to help bring fresh air into rooms, just like your lungs. The command center also controls the heating and air conditioning. It helps the building cool down when it’s too hot and warm up when it’s too cold. A skyscraper has many different parts that work together. The bones make the building tall and strong. The skin protects the inside of the building. The skin of a skyscraper can be made of metal, stone, or glass. The brain controls the building temperature. The anatomy of a skyscraper is like a human body. All the parts have to work together. That's how a city skyscraper works properly.
item_text: What is the main idea of paragraph 3?
option_text: To describe what the backbone of a skyscraper is made of
construct_name: Domain-Specific (Science) Reading Comprehension
title: Replication Data for: Time to Transfer: Long-Term Effects of a Sustained and Spiraled Content Literacy Intervention in the Elementary Grades

construct_name: Domain-Specific (Science) Reading Comprehension
title: Replication Data for: Time to Transfer: Long-Term Effects of a Sustained and Spiraled Content Literacy Intervention in the Elementary Grades
author: James S Kim and Joshua B. Gilbert and Jackie E. Relyea and Patrick Rich and Ethan Scherer and Mary A. Burkhauser and Johanna N. Tvedt

instrument: Comprehension test following a reading intervention
instructions: Now you will read the passage silently by yourself and then answer the questions. There are 4 answer choices for each question but only one correct answer. Choose the answer that you think is correct. You may begin.
section_prompt: A human is a primate. In primates, the heart sends oxygen in the blood all around the body. The body must have oxygen to function properly. The strong heart muscle contracts to pump blood all around the body. A healthy heart never rests. But what happens when a person’s heart gets weaker? People with weak hearts need help. Scientists have to study a medical mystery. Then they might be able to help people. First, scientists need to diagnose the reasons that a human heart gets weak. They need to do tests. But sometimes it would be hard on a sick person to have tests done. So, scientists study animals that have body systems like humans. Scientists knew that the macaque monkey’s heart is similar to the human heart. So, they did tests with macaque monkeys. The scientists learned what happens when a monkey has a heart attack. After a heart attack, the monkey’s heart muscle has scar tissue where it was damaged. The scar tissue cannot contract like a strong heart muscle can. Then the monkey’s heart cannot pump enough blood to give the body the oxygen it needs. Without enough oxygen, the monkey’s body cannot function properly. Second, scientists wanted to try out new solutions that would keep the heart working. Sometimes the new solutions might fail. So, scientists didn’t want to try the solutions with people right away. They tried a solution with macaque monkeys. Scientists developed an idea. Then, they tested an idea. They injected human stem cells from the human heart into the monkey’s heart. After four weeks the human heart cells grew where the monkey’s scar tissue was. After three months, the monkey’s heart got stronger. Now scientists are using what they found in this experiment to help humans who have had heart attacks.
item_text: According to the passage, what is an important function of the heart muscle?
construct_name: Domain-Specific (Science) Reading Comprehension
title: Replication Data for: Time to Transfer: Long-Term Effects of a Sustained and Spiraled Content Literacy Intervention in the Elementary Grades

instructions: The following questions ask about babies’ normal behavior. Each item describeswhat a typical infant might be like, or what could affect the infant’s growth and behavior. Answer each item based on your knowledge of infants in general. We want to know how you think most babies act, how they grown, and how to care for them. After you read each item, decide whether you AGREE, DISAGREE, or are NOT SURE.
section_prompt: Each of the following asks about the age at which infants can do something. If you AGREE with the statement, fill in the 'Agree' circle. If you do not agree, then decide whether a YOUNGER or OLDER child would show the behavior.
item_text: Eighteen month olds often cooperate and share when they play together
construct_name: Knowledge of Infant Development (KIDI)
